application.name: isis2gml
application.brief: output a GML polygon from an ISIS cube
application.description: This program calculates a footprint polygon, in (longitude, lattitude) space, for a cube and outputs a graphical markup language (GML) file containing the polygon. The input cube can be in either camera space (level1) or map projected space (level2). An ID tag can be added to the GML header, see the LABEL parameter.

history.change: Added ability to output either a 0 to 360 longitude domain or -180 to 180 longitude domain polygon. If the cube is map projected (level2) the default will be to match the projection. Also modified the gml output to be more standards compliant including a matching XSD file.

parameter.name: FROM
parameter.description: Input cube to use for polygon generation

parameter.name: TO
parameter.brief: GML formatted file containing the footprint polygon
parameter.description: Use this parameter to specify the name of the output GML file. The output file will be a geographic markup language (GML) file containing a (longitude, lattitude) polygon. If no file name is entered the input cube file name will be used with an extension of "gml". A second output file will be created with the same base name as the "gml" file, but with the extension of "xsl." The "xsl" file is a standard part of the GML output.

parameter.name: LABEL
parameter.brief: Adds an ID tag to the GML header
parameter.description: This value is placed in the GML header within the ID tag. The information within the ID tag can be used by GIS packages to display a label on the footprint. If no value is entered no ID tag will be generated for the GML file.

parameter.name: LONGITUDEDOMAIN
parameter.description: This value controls the longitude domain of the output GML polygons.

option.brief: Use the cube projection domain or 0/360 if not projected
option.description: Longitudes in the GML polygon will be in the same domain as the input cube projection if the cube is projected. If the input cube is not projected longitudes will be in the 0 to 360 domain.
Longitudes within the polygon will be in the 180 to -180 domain
Longitudes within the polygon will be in the 0 to 360 domain
